children.name: regress
children.definition: technicalto go back to an earlier and worse condition, or to a less developed way of behavingOPP progress:thoái bộ, thoái lui
examples: The patient had regressed to a state of childish dependency.

children.name: go badly
children.definition: /not go well if a piece of work or activity goes badly, it does not make progress or develop in the way you would like it to: diễn biến tồi tệ
examples: My essay isn’t going very well. It’s difficult to find any useful books on the subject.
Despite all the government’s efforts, the war on drugs is going badly.

children.name: a situation in which there is no progress
stalemate
children.definition: /ˈsteɪlmeɪt/  a situation in which no further progress can be made because two groups or organizations disagree with each other about what to do, and cannot think of any way to end the disagreement:sự bế tắc
examples: reach a stalemate/be at a stalemate
lâm vào tình trạng bế tắc
▪ At that point the strike appeared to have reached a stalemate.
▪ Negotiations with the 200 army rebels are at a stalemate.
end in stalemate
kết thúc trong bế tắc
▪ It looks like the long-running dispute could end in stalemate.
stalemate between
sự bế tắc giữa
▪ The proposal was aimed at ending the stalemate between environmentalist and business groups.
stalemate in
sự bế tắc trong
▪ the stalemate in the three-month long pay dispute
break a stalemate
xua tan bế tắc
make it possible for discussions to continue
▪ an attempt to break a stalemate in the Middle East peace process

children.name: deadlock
children.definition: /ˈdedlɒkǁ-lɑːk/  a situation in which no further progress can be made because two groups disagree strongly with each other and refuse to change their minds:sự bế tắc
examples: ▪ In the same year the issue came before Parliament, but there was complete deadlock.
deadlock between:sự bế tắc giữa
▪ There are hopes that an agreement can be made to break the deadlock between the White House and Congress.
deadlock over:sự bế tắc trên
▪ The deadlock over the US budget had turned away some investors.
end in deadlock: kết thúc trong bế tắc
▪ Their first trial ended in deadlock when the jury could not reach an agreement.
break a deadlock
xua tan bế tắc
to make it possible to agree so that you can progress
▪ Syria and Israel broke a six-month deadlock in their talks when they sent peace envoys to Maryland.

children.name: dead end
children.definition: /ˌded ˈend◂/  a situation in which it is impossible to make any further progress in your work or in what you are trying to do:tình trạng bế tắc
examples: ▪ My mother thought that I should be a model, but I knew that was a dead end.
be/feel you are at a dead end
cảm thấy bạn đang trongtình trạng bế tắc
▪ At 52, Martin felt he was at a dead end professionally.
come to/hit/reach etc a dead end
vướng vàotình trạng bế tắc
stop making any progress
▪ The development of this drug has come to a dead end because of doubts about its safety.
dead-end[adjective]
bế tắc
▪ A large number of young people who leave school at 16 end up in dead-end jobs.
▪ My sister, Jess, was in a dead-end relationship from which she could see no escape.

children.name: impasse
children.definition: /æmˈpɑːsǁˈɪmpæs/  formal a situation in which progress has stopped completely, especially because people cannot agree on what to do next:ngõ cụt, thế bế tắc
examples: impasse in:bế tắc trong
▪ The continuing impasse in negotiations made military conflict seem likely.
impasse between:bế tắc giữa
▪ an impasse between the US and its European trading partners
impasse over:bế tắc với
▪ There seemed no way to end the impasse over the Lockerbie affair.
reach an impasse/be at an impasse: vướng vàobế tắc
▪ It was clear that the Soviet economy was at an impasse.
▪ On July 25, the situation seemed to have reached an impasse.

children.name: a step backwards
children.definition: /ə ˌstep ˈbækwəʳdz/  an action or change that makes a situation worse, so that the progress that has been made is lost:bước thụt lùi
examples: a step backwards for:bước thụt lùi đối với
▪ Accepting the job would be a step backwards for me.
▪ Several opposition leaders described the programme as a major step backwards for democracy.
take a step backwards
bước thụt lùi
▪ Any sort of stress such as upset in the family may cause a child to take a step backwards in behaviour.
